anchovy drying season starts from November of

Istanbul. Japanese officials are
cautious about the rapid increase in cases of infection with a
rare bacteria, although
experts say it is unlikely that an
epidemic will appear.  Currently, according to Japanese authorities,
the number of cases of toxic shock syndrome
has increased to 30 PH in Tokyo, three times higher
than last year. This syndrome is
caused by group A streptococcus bacteria that can lead
to tissue necrosis and mortality.  The death rate from
this disease is 30 minutes in
2023. Experts say that STSS is not a
serious respiratory disease like
Covid-19, so it is unlikely that it will spread
into an epidemic, although people
should not be subjective about STSS.  is not covid-19
or other infectious diseases.
People only need to practice
common control measures such as washing their hands
to prevent the spread of
group A streptococcus, which can be transmitted through infectious
diseases.  Respiratory droplets and
direct contact as well as through wounds in
the hands or feet, especially when
severely infected, the bacteria will spread throughout the body
through the blood, eating the internal organs, causing
the patient to fall into
coma and even death. Health officials
emphasize the need to take
basic preventative measures such as regular washing
and proper wound care.
